element.tooltip:
Express Report

Quickly create tabular reports with essential operations like sorting, filtering and calculations. Easily format and summarize data.

Advanced Report

Create reports containing charts, maps, gauges, and images. Add group sections to provide more flexibility in how data is displayed.

Crosstab Report

Create reports that pivot data. The number of columns and rows in the crosstab expands based on the data itself.

Dashboard

Create an interactive canvas containing reports, visualizations, images, charts, maps, gauges, text and web pages.

ExpressView

Explore data and get quick answers using drag & drop in a highly-interactive designer.

Chained Report

Combine multiple related or disparate reports into a single export.
Duplicate Report: Make an identical copy of the selected report. This will allow you to have multiple versions of a report without modifying the original copy.
Manage Folders: Create, rename or delete folders and sub folders.

HTML:
Display the report in a tab of the browser.

Excel:
Download the report as an Excel file.

PDF:
Download the report as a PDF file.

RTF:
Download the report as a Word file.

CSV:
Download the report as a Comma Separated Value file.
Provide a unique name to identify the report in the Main Menu.
Provide a description of the report. Descriptions appear at the bottom of the Main Menu and are used when searching for reports.
Select the Data Categories that the report should access.
Select which Data Fields should dictate the order of information on your report.
Apply filters to limit the amount of information displayed on your report.
Select which Data Fields should display on your report.
Configure additional report settings such as page size and orientation.

Layout Options:
- Prevent duplicate values from appearing.
- Provide alternate row shading.
Add a blank column to the report.

Format Cells:
- Specify how numeric, date and text values should display.
- Apply borders to cells.

Themes:
Quickly style your report using a predefined theme.

After selecting Summary Functions on the Data Fields above, use the check boxes below to specify which sorted Categories the functions should display on or if they should be used to create Grand Totals at the end of the the report.

You can click on any of the category names below or Page Header, Page Footer and Grand Totals for additional options.
Create a formula to perform calculations on data.
Provide a unique name to identify the report in the Main Menu.
Provide a description of the report. Descriptions appear at the bottom of the Main Menu and are used when searching for reports.
Select the Data Categories that the report should access.
Select which Data Fields should dictate the order of information on your report.
Apply filters to limit the amount of information displayed on your report.
Add a predesigned PDF, RTF, or Excel template to your report.
Align cell contents to the top of the cell.
Align cell contents to the middle of the cell.
Align cell contents to the bottom of the cell.
Align cell contents to the left of the cell.
Align cell contents to the center of the cell.
Align cell contents to the right of the cell.
Justify cell contents to fit to cell's width.

Merge Cells:
Join the selected cells to create a single large cell. A helpful feature when creating charts, gauges, images and maps.

Split Cells:
Divide the selected merged cell.

Wrap Text:
Wraps the cell's contents onto a new line if it goes past the column's width. When you change the column width, wrapping adjusts automatically.

AutoSum:
Calculate the total value of the selected cell. Only use this for cells in group footer or report footer sections.

Suppress Duplicates:
Prevent a cell from repeating duplicate values on subsequent rows of the report.
Insert Image: Add an image from your computer into a cell.

Crosstab Wizard:
Add a crosstab that expands data both horizontally and vertically. Only use this for cells in group footer or report footer sections.

Formula Editor:
Create formulas to perform calculations on data.

Link Reports:
Link a cell to another report to create a drill-down on HTML output.

ToolbarItems.element:
Chart Wizard:
Charts provide a visual representation of your data.

Geochart Wizard:
Geocharts provide a visual representation of geographic data on a simple map.

Google Map Wizard:
Google Maps provide a visual representation of geographic data on a map, in the style of Google mapping.

Gauge Wizard:
Gauges reflect a scalar data value.

element.tooltip:
Sections:
Sections dictate when rows of a report will appear.

For more information: Click anywhere in the section column and hover over 'Add Section'. Hover over each type of section to see a detailed tooltip.

The rows of a page header section appear at the top of each page.

Example: Column labels that should repeat on each page.

The rows of a report header section appear at the beginning of the report.

Example: The title of the report.

The rows of a detail section appear once for each row of data returned during execution.

Example: The itemized list of a receipt.

The rows of a report footer section appear at the end of the report.

Example: Grand totals or charts that show trends occurring in the detail section.

The rows of a page footer section appear at the bottom of each page.

Example: Page numbers or confidentiality notices.

The rows of a group header section appear at the start of each new value of a sorted Data Field.

Group header sections require that a sort exists.

Example: Display each new customers name above the orders they have made.

The rows of a group footer sections appear at the end of each value of a sorted Data Field. They are typically used to calculate subtotals.

Group footer sections require that a sort exists.

Example: Display each customer's total beneath their orders.

Repeating group sections should be used on a report when you have multiple one-to-many relationships from one Data Category to other Categories and you want each Categoryâ€™s data to appear separately.

Example: On a report you may want to display a list of professors and for each professor, list the classes they teach and list all of their publishings. Each professor may teach multiple classes and may have made multiple publishings (i.e. multiple one-to-many relationships). In this case, you would use two repeating group sections based on Professor: one to display the classes they teach and one to display their publishings.
Select gauge type and size.
Select data values, ranges and color options.
Select chart type, size and color options.
Specify which cells of the report will provide data values for the chart.
Add a title and other labels.
Select map type, size and color options.
Select Data Fields to specify which cells will determine location information.
Specify which cells of the report will provide data values for each location.

For dynamic maps, (only available in HTML output) define the initial location view of the map.

For static maps, define which view the map image should take.

Enabling 'Display Drop Pins' will cause pushpins representing the most granular region type to appear when drilling into the most granular metric level. For example, if the most granular region type is 'City' and the most granular metric level is 'State', enabling this setting will cause pushpins to mark City data points when drilling into a State.

Select all region types by which the metrics should aggregate. Ex. Checking Country and City will aggregate values per Country by default, and drilling into Country will display values aggregated per City.

Row header sources expand the crosstab vertically.

Select the Data Fields that determine how many rows are in the crosstab.

Column header sources expand the crosstab horizontally.

Select the Data Fields that determine how many columns are in the crosstab.

Tabulation data sources display summary information where row and column header sources intersect.

Select Data Fields to be summarized when data exists for both the row and column headers.
Add the selected Data Field as a row header source.
Add the selected Data Field as a column header source.
Add the selected Data Field as a tabulation source.
Drag this item onto the canvas to add a pre-existing report.
Drag this item onto the canvas to add a new data visualization.
Drag this item onto the canvas to add text.
Drag this item onto the canvas to add an image.
Drag this onto item the canvas to add a filter.
Drag this item onto the canvas to add a web page.

Round Edges
Round the corners of the selected item's borders.
The filter's operator determines the procedure used to compare the Data Field to the filter value.

Specify the relationship between filters.

Select AND to require that the selected filter and the one below are both true.

Select OR to require that either the selected filter or the one below it are true.
Place parentheses around the selected filter and the one that follows.
Allow the selected filter to be modified when the report is run.

Determine whether or not to display the search, paging and export options on HTML output.

Settings: - Auto: Dynamically hide the toolbar if the report only displays a Report Footer Section
- Show: Toolbars will always be displayed.
- Hide: Toolbars will always be hidden.

Example: Set to Auto to hide the toolbar for reports that only contain a single Chart or Map in a Report Footer Section.
